page.normal_text:
RF phase shaking for bunch distribution modification
RF phase shaking for bunch distribution modification
page.title:
Alexey Burov
Alexey Burov

Motivation
Motivation
page.enlisting:
• Tevatron bunches are known to demonstrate longitudinal instability sometimes called as “dancing bunches” [1]. Similar phenomena happen at other machines as well. • There are some theoretical indications showing that this instability is sensitive to a derivative of the phase space density f '(J)=df/dJ at small actions, f '(J→0). • Distributions with flat or even positive slope of the distribution density at small • However, IBS always tries to make this derivative negative, df/dJ -f/Jrms . Thus, the problem emerges - is it possible to zero this derivative or even change its sign by one or another meaning? • Tevatron bunches are known to demonstrate longitudinal instability sometimes called as “dancing bunches” [1]. Similar phenomena happen at other machines as well.
• Tevatron bunches are known to demonstrate longitudinal instability sometimes

as well.

page.title:
RF phase shaking
RF phase shaking
page.enlisting:
• • Technically, easiest way for that would be modulation of the RF phase with a synchrotron frequency for small amplitude particles. Then, a width of the affected area is determined by an amplitude of that phase modulation . •
•
• Technically, easiest way for that would be modulation of the RF phase with a synchrotron frequency for small amplitude particles. Then, a width of the affected area is determined by an amplitude of that phase modulation .
• Technically, easiest way for that would be modulation of the RF phase with
a synchrotron frequency for small amplitude particles. Then, a width of the
affected area is determined by an amplitude of that phase modulation .
It is known that the distribution function tends to flatten inside resonance separatrices. Thus, the desired change of the distribution may be achieved by introducing a proper resonance for small amplitude particles. Due to nonlinearity of the synchrotron motion, large amplitude particles could be only slightly disturbed by that.
It is known that the distribution function tends to flatten inside resonance
separatrices. Thus, the desired change of the distribution may be achieved
by introducing a proper resonance for small amplitude particles. Due to
nonlinearity of the synchrotron motion, large amplitude particles could be
only slightly disturbed by that.

page.title:
Simulations
Simulations
page.enlisting:
• To see how this mapping changes the distribution function, tracking of N=104 particles was simulated on a base of Mathematica. Original distribution over unperturbed actions J was taken as • The amplitude of the RF phase modulation was taken . The synchrotron phase advance was taken as , and the simulation time Tsim=500 synchrotron radians = 80 synchrotron periods. • To see how this mapping changes the distribution function, tracking of N=104 particles was simulated on a base of Mathematica. page.title:
Conclusions
Conclusions
page.enlisting:
• RF phase modulation is clearly working tool for flattening of the distribution function. From this point of view, it should help to stabilize longitudinal instability [2]. • The simulation mapping does not take into account the wake field. Wakes lead to potential well distortion, depressing synchrotron frequencies, so slightly reducing the required frequency of the RF modulation. • Continuing beam studies are needed with the bunch profile measurements. • RF phase modulation is clearly working tool for flattening of the distribution function. From this point of view, it should help to stabilize longitudinal instability [2].
• RF phase modulation is clearly working tool for flattening of the distribution
function. From this point of view, it should help to stabilize longitudinal
instability [2].
• The simulation mapping does not take into account the wake field. Wakes lead to potential well distortion, depressing synchrotron frequencies, so slightly reducing the required frequency of the RF modulation.
• The simulation mapping does not take into account the wake field. Wakes
lead to potential well distortion, depressing synchrotron frequencies, so
slightly reducing the required frequency of the RF modulation.
• Continuing beam studies are needed with the bunch profile measurements.
• Continuing beam studies are needed with the bunch profile measurements.
• Although RF phase modulation itself excites coherent motion at some level, it should not make a significant problem. Indeed, this RF modulation is needed only for ~ 100 synchrotron revolutions or so, and after that it has to be switched off. The provided distribution should be stable, so any coherent motion should decay.
• Although RF phase modulation itself excites coherent motion at some level,
it should not make a significant problem. Indeed, this RF modulation is
needed only for ~ 100 synchrotron revolutions or so, and after that it has to
be switched off. The provided distribution should be stable, so any coherent
motion should decay.
